posts.post_content: With the right deck this guy is one heck of a rattlesnake. I like playing [Necropotence](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Necropotence) + [Spellbook](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Spellbook) with this guy, and just when my opponents thinks the situation couldn't get any worse, I play [Xathrid Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Xathrid Demon).

posts.post_content: In the right deck this card doubles as both a well-costed fatty and brutal board wipe. If your deck sports black and a consistent decently large hand-size, it's a serious mistake to not include a couple of this chunker.

Posted By: Amphetadex (8/11/2009 9:37:28 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
By a most wonderful of coincidences, this guy's name both refers to the original and recurring [Maro](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Maro) mechanic **and** is a proper Ja panese name.  
  
Maro is a recurring suffix for boys names, meaning something along the lines of 'me' or 'I'.  
  
Transliterated; Kagemaro means approximately "Great One of Shadow".
posts.html:

Transliterated; Kagemaro means approximately "Great One of Shadow".

posts.post_content:
@axelle: HairlessThoctar meant that it was a coincidence that Wizards could print a card with the word "Maro" in it while still creating a correct Ja panese name.   
  
For those that don't know, the Maro mechanic (named for lead designer Mark Rosewater) is a tradition where every creature that references hand size has the word Maro in its name. Just search 'maro' in gatherer and you'll see it.
posts.html:
@axelle: HairlessThoctar meant that it was a coincidence that Wizards could print a card with the word "Maro" in it while still creating a correct Ja panese name.

For those that don't know, the Maro mechanic (named for lead designer Mark Rosewater) is a tradition where every creature that references hand size has the word Maro in its name. Just search 'maro' in gatherer and you'll see it.
